@AutismFractal @jessejanderson It's ok to only eat a few meals if that's what works. Take a good multivitamin if you can to get those micro nutrients.  It's better to eat the same vaguely balanced meal every day than end up in debt from wasting food.

@AutismFractal @jessejanderson One of the things I've found helpful is to be honest w myself about foods I will or won't use. I rotate a handful of dishes, use frozen veg and fruit so it doesn't waste, and minimise stuff I risk not using like fresh fruit & greens. It's not perfect but it helps.

@BootstrapCook It takes a few days of being really consistent and ignoring the urge to yeet something out the window. Expect a few days poor sleep. It's worth it though. Our newer cats even learned from their older siblings!

@BootstrapCook I've successfully used Jackson Galaxys method. Feed set mealtimes, no free feeding. Playtime an hr b4 bed, then feed. once lights out ignore him complete. If causing damage just move him, don't speak or eye contact.

So for the avoidance of all doubt...every disabled person is self ID-ing as such. That's literally how this works. If you think someone is a bad person for self ID-ing, then you can fuck right off. You're all one bad day away from being disabled, so get a fucking grip.
We are disabled because we live in a society that doesn't cater for our needs as people with impairments. And disabled people are the experts in our own experience.
And don't get me started on benefits 😑 Just...don't.

Registered disabled isn't a thing. Like, there isn't some database of disabled people you get added to. I've even had GPs try to tell me to 'get registered disabled'! Like, some local authorities used to do it, kinda, but it's not universal or necessary.

Diagnosis can take years. Decades, even. I was still disabled before I was diagnosed, there just wasn't a label stuck on my impairment. This is because disability and impairment are not the same thing.

It constantly amazes me what non disabled ppl imagine the process is. That you walk into your GPs, get a diagnosis that day, are registered disabled' and get handed benefits. Idk what you lot think, but that's not how it works.
...I'm disabled. That's a fact. Every disabled person self IDs as such. There's no other way. We are the only ones who can judge whether we fit either the legal definitions, or the lived reality.

Because the whole 'self ID-ing as disabled' thing is doing the rounds...There is no such thing as being diagnosed as disables. Your doctor will not tell you that you are disabled. There is nothing in my medical records that says 'Sophie is disabled'. And yet...
@what_eats_owls The best bit is that we've all collectively somehow agreed not to notice the implications.

11/ And get your booster. With Omicron the booster is what makes the difference, so get that as soon as you can. The vaccines are safe, tested, and reliable. They save lives. /End.

10/ please take care of each other. Spending Christmas isolating is far better than risking your relatives getting sick, getting long covid, or even dying. I know it's hard, but please, please do the right thing.
9/ if your home test is positive, get a PCR at test right away, and isolate until you get the results.

8/ covid has an incubation period of anything form 2-8 ish days, depending on the variant. This means if you take a test the day after an event this tells you NOTHING about whether you are infected. Keep doing home tests and get a PCR at first sign of symptoms.
7/ If you are going to an event or family gathering, take a home test BEFORE you go.

6/ I've heard of a lot of folks not taking a test in case it is positive and they can't do the thing they wanted to do. This is extremely irresponsible. If you are asymptomatic you risk causing immense harm or even death to other people.
5/ If you are positive you should isolate for 10 days from the date of your test.
4/ You should self isolate while waiting for PCR test results. I appreciate this is really fucking hard when sick pay is so low and employers are being shits.

3/ If you had close contact w someone who tests positive, or have symptoms (even if u think it's a cold or allergies) a PCR test is essential. This is a much more accurate test & identifies covid much earlier.

2/ Home tests are great if you don't have symptoms to check if you maybe have covid but are asymptomatic. They are less accurate but if used regularly will help pick up asymptomatic folks and so reduce the spread. This is really important to reduce pressure on the NHS.

So yeah, that's my crappy date story. I'm going to spend a bit of time being very kind to myself and being damn proud that I recognised what was happening, named it, and did what I needed to do to be safe. (end)

Most sexual assault is just as mundane and it's easy to brush it off as not really an issue. But the trauma adds up, and it changes us in ways that are painful and complex. None of us deserve to be treated as so much disposable flesh. We deserve better. 12/?

So I'm fine. And I'm safe. But to be clear, what he did was sexual assault. He alone holds the responsibility for that. I communicated my boundaries and he repeatedly overstepped them. He had a choice, and he had a responsibility to make sure I was comfortable. 11/?

It kills me how easy it is to say 'would it be ok if I...' or 'i'd love to...' and yet how the idea never seems to cross people's minds. And you know, I'm pretty sure this guy thinks he's a good man, that he'd never harm a woman. And yet here we fucking are. 10/?

What hurt the most wasn't having my boundaries violated by yet another man for whom consent is apparently a mystery. It was that I shrugged it off so easily as the risk inherent in dating cis men. It was how mundane the whole thing was. 9/?

When I got home I messaged my friends and started the process of figuring out how to get away from this guy in a safe way. And today I messaged him, spelled out what he'd done, and blocked him. But what hurt the most wasn't what he did. 8/?

So when he checked the train times and we walked to the station together, it was a relief. When he said something about seeing me again I smiled and nodded, and the second I turned my back and headed for my platform that smile vanished. 7/?

So when he went in for a kiss again, I let him. And his hands went to all the places I'd told him not to. And the knot in my stomach got tighter. And he asked me, for maybe the third time, to come back to his, and I told him 'no'. Again. 6/?

So I squashed that feeling. And he put his hands under my top, and into my bra and I pulled back and told him 'behave' and he said 'sorry'. And there was a moment when I thought maybe he *was* sorry. Maybe he realised he'd ignored my boundaries 5/?

This is the point where I should have got up and walked out. But here's the thing. We're socialised not to make a fuss. And especially for those of us who have survived sexual violence, it can feel deeply unsafe to push back. When I don't feel safe I appease. 4/?

[Pause here for a CN for sexual assault] It was good until he pulled my hand towards his crotch. I pulled it back, and he kept pulling. When I got my hand free, I noticed that there was a knot in my stomach that hadn't been there a few seconds ago. 3/?

And at first, it was good. He told me about the race he'd run, I told him about my work day. We grinned at each other like fools because it was so good to meet in the flesh. When he went in for a kiss, that was good too. Until it wasn't. 2/?

I am a ball of seething rage at the moment, and as usual, the reason is A Man. In this case, a man I went on date with. Who I thought was kind, and fun, and smart, and hot. We'd been chatting a few weeks, and met up for the first time for an afternoon brew. 1/?

The way our society treats mental illness is beyond broken. No amount of corporate platitudes and tweets about nature or whatever will fix a system that sees seeking attention as wrong.

So if youre a MH pro who frames attention seeking as negative, I'd urge you to re-examine that. It's an approach rooted in gatekeeping & bias & it means the ppl who need support the most won't get it.

Attention seeking is positive. It means you know you need help and you are trying to get it. It is not your fault if you can't figure out what you need or how to get help. You deserve to be heard and supported regardless.
Ultimately it is up to MH pros to support ppl in identifying their needs & helping them access the support that is right for them, however that request for help is presented.

So we've got a group of ppl who do not always have the capacity to seek support in a way that matches what the MH services want, who are highly vulnerable & in most need of support, but who get their healthy behaviour - seeking attention - pathologised.

Problem is often the tools ppl have are not the 'best' & the coping mechanisms they've developed are long term harmful. And we have a system that sees that and says 'unless you approach in the way we say is right, you won't get help'

But on some level they've identified that their needs re not being met and they are using the tools they do have to seek help. That is a really positive thing. Reaching out for support, no matter how it's done, is a good thing.

When someone seeks attention it's because they need attention. Revolutionary analysis, I know. Thing is, often folks who are in crisis lack the tools/resources (emotional, physical, financial, etc) to identify their needs.
So, let's talk about "attention seeking". Coz one of the things we hear a lot wrt to mental health is that ppl attention seek & that this is a bad thing. It isn't.

@KyrstieStubbs We would rather the realities of our struggles be recognised & ppl show genuine allyship than ppl try to find terms that sound less upsetting (mainly to abled ppl!)

@KyrstieStubbs Also just to say, I'm not offended - unless u use slurs most of us are unlikely to be. But it's frustrating because the term presents an idea of disability that just doesn't exist. There are no 'different abilities' that we gain on becoming disabled.

@KyrstieStubbs As standard, not as an added extra, and where disabled ppl get full access to society. We use the social model of disability - that we are disabled by society, not by our impairments. In that context differently abled doesn't make a lot of sense.

@KyrstieStubbs Differently abled suggests we get some kind of magic extra abilities instead of the ones we lose, but the truth is disability often does mean we lack certain abilities. And that's ok! The disability rights movement is focussed on moving to a society where our needs are met

@KyrstieStubbs I'm an EDI educator so get how hard this is, & it's great you are listening to ppl & making change. You'll never please everyone coz disabled ppl are not a monolith & we all have different views. That said, as a rule disabled ppl prefer to be called disabled.

We deserve better, and although this guidance doesn't apply to me as someone w secondary chronic pain it's still deeply frightening & angering on behalf of those it will impact directly. The impact will be felt by all of us.

The NHS is consistently bad at dealing with chronic pain and this guidance, while in places really beneficial, is very likely to be interpreted by individual docs in a way that undermines access to appropriate pain management.

I'd like to try reducing my pain meds but am afraid that if I do I won't be allowed to increase again if the lower dose doesn't work out. That shouldn't be the case. We all deserve good pain management, and we all deserve to be trusted & heard when we say what works for us.

Noone ever told me what addiction looked like, or the difference between addiction & dependence. Noone told me that chronic pain patients are far less likely to experience addiction. I still live in fear of having my meds taken away.

Better education of patients so we know what addiction looks & feels like & a supportive environment so we feel safe asking for support if we are worried, without fearing that we will be left without pain management.

What is like to see as a patient who takes boat loads of opiates to manage my pain, is for much better management of patients. Proper access to pain clinics, non judgemental support so we don't get made to feel like criminals when we ask for meds.

I appreciate that opiates can be harmful, but ultimately we all deserve to access good pain management. Pain is trauma, it's deeply harmful and it has long term impacts on physical and mental health. Regardless of whether a cause can be found pain is valid & needs addressing.

Now that I'm diagnosed I have great pain relief, but if I'd not had painkillers until the point of diagnosis I'd have started from a much worse position. Those meds gave me the opportunity to put in place the groundwork for my future. I'd never be where I am now without them.

Telling me to exercise more would have achieved nothing other than making my life miserable & increasing my pain. Doubt I'd have graduated, certainly wouldn't have done a master's, likely wouldn't have been able to work.

It took a decade for me to be diagnosed w endometriosis & longer for EDS & fibromyalgia. Prescription painkillers during that time allowed me to complete my education, work, & have a social life.  https://t.co/oWs6hK3695

Consent isn't just a yes or a no. It's an ongoing conversation, not just verbally but through body language & much more. It's about enthusiastic consent from everyone involved, actively engaged with & where 'no' is a genuine option without negative consequences 8/
